On Fri, 7 Nov 2003, Matt wrote:

> > I'm saying that the TestCase subclasses define & embody the
> fixture.
> > The realization of the fixture (in an instance of the TestCase
> > subclass)  is the collection of objects that are under test.  Note
> > that the fixture is not just the objects, but their state as well.
> > You may have instance of the same classes, but with different state
> > (e.g. empty list, one element, two elements...). They are different
> > fixtures and should be in different TestCase subclasses.
>
> Question about this.  Obviously each 'object' can have its own state
> but through static attributes each class can have its own state
> also.  How do you deal with that with reference to this discussion?

The idea is to define a set of objects which are reinitialized before
each test.  You do this to avoid contamination between tests.  Clearly
you could reinitialize static variables for use as part of a fixture.
But it's cleaner to create brand-new objects for use in the fixture.

If you use static variables of the TestCase, you have to be careful.  If
you create new objects, you don't have to think so much.  So create new
objects.  Who wants to think?

;-)
